text: What’s up guys? Jared again.

If you’ve already seen John Wick 3, maybe
you noticed the same strange phenomenon in

the theater that I did.
Specifically, the audience’s reaction during

the movie’s plentiful fight sequences, which
go down everywhere from a New York Public

Library to a conveniently placed glass hall
of knives. Now, John Wick has never been afraid

to take one, or several dozen, human lives
as swiftly, efficiently and nonchalantly as

a quality sous chef chopping onions. But the
deaths this time around were wilder and more

intense than ever. And yet they were also…
pretty freakin’ hilarious? Truly, I’ve

never seen an audience simultaneously wince
and laugh, but John Wick 3 just kind of demands

that very unique reaction. This puzzled us,
and led to a lot of pondering on the nature

of comedy and also a lot of arguing about
whether the spine of a library book could

really do that. We think we can locate the
source of the film’s strange, perhaps even

sadistic, sense of humor by looking back on
the history of American cinematic comedy,

more specifically, slapstick humor. So welcome
to this Wisecrack Edition on John Wick 3:

Or “Are We Sickos For Thinking This Is Effing
Hilarious?” And soooorta spoilers ahead,
but nothing too revealing.

But first, a quick recap. John Wick is on
the run with a 14 million dollar bounty on

his head because he killed this unpleasant
crime lord and... Ok let’s be honest, the

details of the plot are NOT THAT important
to any of these films.

The only thing you really need to know is
that in the first movie some mobsters killed

the dog John Wick’s deceased wife gave to
him. Since then, Wick has mowed down a fun

array of gangsters in the name of symbolic
doggie justice.

Wick hits, maims, kills, and sasses a potpourri
of stuntmen. He shows affection only to his

dog. That’s pretty much the whole deal and
it’s amazing. In order to figure out why

John Wick makes us lol, we’re going to leave
it for a second and explore the black and

white chaos of American film history until
we find... This guy. Meet Buster Keaton, famous

silent film maker and bringer of the gnarliest
stunts the 1920s ever did witness. [Series

of famous Buster Keaton stunts] Keaton, along
with other greats like Charlie Chaplin and

Mack Sennett, are seminal figures in the history
of American cinema and specifically slapstick.

Slapstick is a lazy translation of the Italian
word battachio which is the name of this stage

prop, a wooden stick used by clowns in the
Italian tradition of commedia dell’arte.

Even though the pieces of wood are thin, when
you hit someone with it, the stick makes a

huge noise without actually inflicting pain.
That brings us to a main ingredient of slapstick:

what the Encyclopedia Britannica calls “outrageous
make-believe violence,” that is specifically

comedic in nature. Scholar Andrew Stott also
notes that slapstick is “generally understood

as physical humour of a robust and hyperbolized
nature where stunts, acrobatics, pain and

violence are standard features.” Furthermore,
slapstick is kind of mean. As Larry Langman

explains, it ‘implies the use of physical
gags aimed against someone for laugh” and

is decidedly over the top due to the “improbability
of the stunts.” While broad comedy like

slapstick has been around since the ancient
Greek playwright Aristophanes put pen to papyrus,

slapstick itself, specifically materialized
in early American cinema comedies. Characters

in slapstick films went through a LOT. We’re
not just talking about pies in the face. We’re

talking buildings falling down, motorcycles
crashing, people being bopped on the head

with batons, the works. Buster Keaton literally
broke his neck filming this scene [Sherlock

Jr], and didn’t notice until a doctor told
him years later. So what does this have to

do with John Wick? Well a lot more than you
think. The filmmakers even alludes to the

king of physical comedy in the opening scene
of John Wick 2 - look closely and you’ll

see a Buster Keaton film being projected on
the wall of this building. What’s more we

see A Keaton film AGAIN in the opening shots
of John Wick 3. It’s as if the filmmaker

is begging us to make this connection. So
we will.

Let’s start with the premise of John Wick
- a dude goes on a killing spree to avenge

his dead dog.
So on the one hand we have these dozens of

dead bodies. On the other, this dead dog.
The filmmakers could have had Wick set out

to avenge a dead wife or child. Instead, they
have him avenge a symbolic, canine representation

of said wife. This is both kind of sincere,
and kind of ridiculous. Clip: Aurelio: Yeah,

well, because you stole John Wick's car sir
and, uh, killed his dog. Vigo: Oh. By picking

a dog, and constantly leaning into the joke
of it, the filmmakers heavily emphasize the

absurdity, the sheer excess of Wick’s response.
Remember, slapstick thrives on excess. Then

there are the frequent and weirdly hilarious
references to Wick’s “puppy,” to which

he’ll reply, deadly serious, that "John:
It wasn't just a puppy." Having Wick’s response

to his dog’s murder be so outsized and disproportionate
doesn’t just set a backdrop for humor - it

also comments on the way some of our favorite
action heroes tend to create an arguably unnecessary

amount of carnage. [EXAMPLE BAD DECISION MAKING
IN ACTION FILM] Then, there’s the pure excess

and absurdity of the action. Keanu headshots
hundreds of people throughout the film, many

at point blank range. He kills two guys with
a pencil "[Other Guy: I know I've heard the

story sir- RUSSIAN GUY: WITH A F*CKING PENCIL!
WHO THE F*CK CAN DO THAT?]" He stabs one dude

in the eye. He rides piggyback on a sumo wrestler
while shooting him repeatedly in the head.

And did we mention, uh, the library book?
The violence in the third installment goes

beyond its bullet-ridden predecessors and
enters a whole new world of horse kicks to

the head, dog bites to the jugular, and knives
ramming into bald heads. It’s total utter

insanity. Now obviously, there are many differences
between John Wick’s badass avenging and

Buster Keaton’s clowning. Perhaps most significantly,
characters don’t typically die in slapstick

movies.That adds another layer to why this
particular modern brand of slapstick is completely

cringe-worthy and totally funny. To understand,
let’s look to your really basic cousin’s

favorite thinker, Sigmund Freud. Freud was
totally in it for the lolz and loved thinking

about the way humor relates to the unconscious.
Specifically, he saw laughter as a convenient

way to release the uncomfortable feelings
that we keep pent up as we deal with awkward

Thanksgiving dinners, awkward run-ins with
our exes, and awkward handshakes when your

fingers are sticky from eating a popsicle,
etc. In his book Humor, scholar Terry Eagleton’s

uses Freud as a jumping off point for understanding
the hilariousness of jokes dealing with death.

He explains that death is one of those fears
we majorly repress, given that is a super

significant, scary and not-funny thing. Thus,
facing that fear directly, through an onscreen

movie death, means having that repression
“momentarily disarmed” vis a vis book

to spine. And it’s perversely comforting.
As a result, “ the energy we invest in repressing

the fact of our own mortality can be discharged
in laughter.” Basically, laughing at onscreen

death gives us a momentary break from being
effing terrified of us or a loved one or Bill

Murray ever dying. There’s more to it, though.
Eagleton also notes that “humor involves

a brutal disregard for human value, a value
that we nevertheless continue to cherish.We

can dip in to senselessness for a blessed
moment without having to sign on for some

of its more frightful consequences.” Because
we give human life, particularly Bill Murray’s,

the highest value, watching a life be completely
devalued is shocking, and thus funny. Watch

the way this guy’s head explodes. Or how
this body-building enthusiast falls backwards

into the pool. Or how this guy flies through
the air like a ragdoll. It’s harsh and disrespectful

as hell and also… kind of hilarious. But
not every death in John Wick is funny. The

dog dying is devastating. Certain characters
get a little more screen-time or emotional

investment. Here’s a moment where it might
be helpful to consider a quote from filmmaker

Mel Brooks “Tragedy is when I cut my finger.
Comedy is when you fall into an open sewer

and die.” We only laugh at the pain of others
when we are effectively distanced from their

internal experience. In John Wick, fight choreography
and cinematography effectively treat 90% of

the lives depicted on screen as entirely disposable,
unworthy of even the mildest millisecond of

reflection, much less grief. Take this moment
- Wick swiftly kills one, two guys, and then

out of ammo. Shoves the muzzle into a third
guy's chest, giving said man an intimate view

of the cartridge being loaded that will end
his life. This moment is cartoonishly funny

- forcing us to remember that each of these
men is either dead or bleeding to DEATH, while

simultaneously adding in a brief gag that
only highlights the complete disposability

of this man's life. We see a similar gag in
John Wick One. "Goon: *Grunts*" These movies

are basically Buster Keaton, but with headshots.
--

So in conclusion, by laughing at the deaths
of John Wick’s many opponents, we’re NOT

proving ourselves to be overly-media-saturated,
heartless sadists. We’re actually following

in the grand and sacred tradition of American
moviegoers cackling at people experiencing

horrible pain. So what do you think? Does
John Wick count as slapstick? And is laughing

at death a helpful way to deal with our overwhelming,
paralyzing fear of our own mortality? Let

us know in the comments. In the meantime,
we’re gonna be googling “How to not die

soon, please.” Thanks to all our patrons
who support the channel and our podcast. Be

sure to hit that subscribe button.
---
And as always, thank you so
much for watching guys, peace.
